none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, June 8, 1880
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, June 8, 1880
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 6 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]
Brenham Texas.
June 8th 1880.

Dear Professor -
Your letter of 6th Inst reached me
to day - Glad to hear from you - I wrote you
a short letter two days ago - & sent you a paper
I learn to-day from what I deem good
authority, that our quondam friend Prof H
will seek a restoration to his lost honors at
the approaching meeting of your Board -
This intelligence comes from Whitney, & I think
is reliably - He, of course, will strike for
his old chair - I received some weeks
since a precious-elect paper - in the
form & style of a general & special
"endorsation" - I lost it - Thus ends the
first Scene - Put your house in order -
I suggested to you some months since
that your channel to success I thought
was through Col Jones - I think so still

**Transcription of a Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's break this down. The task is to accurately transcribe this handwritten letter from Brenham, Texas, dated June 8th, 1880. It looks like it's addressed to a "Professor," and the ink is faded but mostly legible. I'm going to take this line by line, paying close attention to the details, especially the more difficult words and phrases. My aim is to be as precise as possible, while also recognizing that handwriting can be open to interpretation. I need to make the text machine-readable, and respect the handwritten intent as much as possible, while formatting appropriately. First, the header: "Brenham Texas" and "June 8th 1880." That's straightforward, but important for context. Then the salutation: "Dear Professor -". Okay. Now, into the body. Here we go. ```html

[Header]
Brenham Texas.
June 8th 1880.

Dear Professor -
Your letter of 6th Inst reached me
to day - Glad to hear from you - I wrote you
a short letter two days ago - & sent you a paper
I learn to-day from what I deem good
authority, that our quondam friend Prof H
will seek a restoration to his lost honors at
the approaching meeting of your Board -
This intelligence comes from Whitney, & I think
is reliably - He, of course, will strike for
his old chair - I received some weeks
since a precious-elect paper - in the
form & style of a general & special
"endorsation" - I lost it - Thus ends the
first Scene - Put your house in order -
I suggested to you some months since
that your channel to success I thought
was through Col Jones - I think so still

``` That should be the full transcription. I had to focus on difficult words like "quondam," "reliably," "precious-elect," and "endorsation". The sentence "I think is reliably" is grammatically odd, but I've transcribed what I see, while making an important note that it could be a grammatical slip, or an adverbial use. The "precious-elect" is tricky, but I've determined based on the letters "e-l-e-c-t", and contextual clues. The underlined phrase is "I lost it", indicating emphasis. The formatting should capture that as desired. All done!

[1880, June 8]

Let me know your prospects - & Command
me - if you need me - I thank you for the
Kind notice by Gov. Brown of our friend -
He merits it all & much more - A great
heart & a luminous intellect have gone out -
I did not see the notice of his death in the News -
except the short telegram from Henderson -
You know my estimate of the News -
Our Exercises begin here on 14 & close 23rd -
Yours I see take place at same time -
Gather what you can at Commencement -
all that may affect my friends or whatever
may be personal to myself - When may
we expect you in Brenham - Let me know
that I may be at home - I saw your
friend G. W. Moore this P.M. - He is quite well
We will all enjoy your visit - Busy does
not express my condition just now -
Your friend
[Signature] J. T. Hand

**The Transcription Process: A Deep Dive** Okay, so I'm presented with a handwritten letter image, and my task is crystal clear: transcribe it with meticulous accuracy, adhering to these specific HTML guidelines. It's my forte! The initial scan reveals a cursive script, a bit hurried but readable, and a pencil-written date that clearly seems like an archival addition. The ink, a rich purple-brown, and the gentle folds of the paper are merely contextual observations. First, the date: `[1880, June 8]`. Then, the transcription begins. Each line is painstakingly examined. The goal? To capture every nuance: the original spelling, punctuation (or lack thereof), and the essence of the handwriting. "Let me know your prospects - & Command..." I'm already thinking about those HTML tags, especially `
` for line breaks. Is "prospects" clear? Yes. "Gov. Brown"... that period is essential. "Exercises begin here on 14 & close 23rd..." the superscript "rd" in "23rd" demands the `` tag. I'm noting the unusual ampersand. As I go, contextual clues emerge. "Brenham" in line 14 rings a bell. The mention of "Gov. Brown" and a "friend" point to a potential historical context, maybe even relating to Texas. I'm mentally checking the relevant historical figures. J.T. Hand, Baylor University, Brenham. That seems right. I'm focusing on deciphering the details. The "G. W. Moore" in line 16 and "P.M." are also important bits. I'm constantly refining. "At some time" or "At same time?" I revisit the letter formations. Now, with more close observation, it's definitively "same" – the loop connects like an 'a'. It's the same throughout. I'm rechecking, ensuring "Brenham" and "Henderson" are accurate. Even checking the capitalization of "News" – likely the name of a newspaper. The structure is key: a date, the body of the letter, and the signature. Finally, the HTML structure starts to form. I wrap the date with brackets in a paragraph tag. I use `
` to replicate the original line breaks. Then it's the signature. A small adjustment and final inspection to confirm that everything – every single detail, from "Gov." to the `` tag, is present and correct. The final output is ready. Done.
